Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH:: Genetic sources of novel jaw morphology among Bahamian pupfish (genus Cyprinodon)
Award.AbstractNarration:
Understanding the origins of evolutionary novelty is fundamental to the study of biological diversity. Many studies have focused on the role of selection in driving change. However, a complete picture of the evolutionary process must also account for the mechanisms that create variation. This project investigates genetic changes that produce variation in the jaws of a recently diverged group of fish, and will provide insight into the nature of genetic changes associated with evolution in wild populations. The work will train a graduate in genomic research, and provide research opportunities for undergraduate students interested in careers in science. The researchers will create materials designed for use in K-12 classrooms about fish evolution that highlight how evolutionary novelties arise.

The researchers will investigate the genetic and developmental basis of cranial modifications in recently diverged incipient species of Bahamian pupfish (Cyprinodon). The work addresses the role of gene regulation and sequence divergence in producing novel phenotypic change associated with speciation in three closely-related species that specialize on eating either the scales of other fish or hard-shelled prey or detritus. The project will identify whether the genes and regulatory changes producing pupfish jaw diversity are homologous to those identified in other classic radiations, thus informing our understanding of the extent to which similar genetic mechanisms underlie phenotypic change in disparate lineages. Importantly, the project also aims to identify previously unknown genes associated with evolutionary changes to jaw morphology. The researchers will use high throughput sequencing (RNA-seq) to characterize the extent of regulatory divergence and sequence divergence among the Bahamian forms and the widespread marine outgroup. They will investigate how patterns of transcriptional regulation have diverged among Bahamian forms and identify gene regulatory changes associated with the diversification of jaw morphology. These data will, furthermore, be used to identify sequence variation (SNPs) associated with phenotypic divergence and reproductive isolation in the system. This project will thus provide insight into the genetic changes associated with speciation and the evolution of morphological novelties during the early stages of diversification.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Ezra Lencer has completed the project Genetic sources of novel jaw morphology among Bahamian pupfish (genus Cyprinodon). This project was conducted as part of his Ph.D. dissertation research on the role of gene regulation in the origins of novel phenotypic variation which will be completed in 2017.

As part of this project Ezra travelled to the Bahamas to collect wild fish for a breeding colony of Cyprinodon pupfishes at Cornell. He then collected a developmental series for this group that allowed him to accurately assess developmental stage for each species. He successfully bred multiple species of pupfish and used his staging series to sample and micro-dissect stage- matched tissues for RNA-seq analysis. Laboratory work to document all expressed genes was completed in 2015. Gene sequences from this project were used in collaboration with Wes Warren at Washington University to annotate the C. variegatus genome for use by both this project as well as to produce a resource available to the larger research community. Bioinformatic analyses of expressed genes were conducted during 2015-2016, and Ezra is currently working on producing a manuscript. Additional discoveries that have emerged from this comparative analysis of the genomes of 4 closely related species are also being pursued and will eventually be published and available to the scientific community. 

The overarching goal of this project was to understand how modifications to gene regulation produce variation in jaw shape and size in 4 closely related and ecologically differentiated pupfish species from San Salvador Island, Bahamas (genus Cyprinodon). A central question to this project concerned how much gene expression divergence separates closely related species during the early stages of species formation. Ezra used RNA-seq to show that gene expression divergence among species of pupfish was low as would be expected among recently diversified species. Thus, unlike the relatively large differences in expression levels observed among pathologies (e.g. normal versus cancer cell lines) or among different organs and developmental stages within the same species, gene expression divergence between species during the early stages of diversification tends to be modest and limited to a smaller number of genes.

Despite only modest expression divergence among taxa, data from this project shows that gene expression profiles are more similar among individuals within a species than between species. Interestingly, differences in morphology are less predictive of gene expression divergence than time since species formation. This result is significant, because it shows that genome wide levels of expression divergence may be relatively decoupled from phenotypic divergence at a macro-evolutionary scale.

This project, furthermore, identified modifications to gene expression that are likely to contribute to the evolution of novel jaw morphologies in Cyprinodon pupfishes. A subset of these genes were previously known to affect jaw shape and size from biomedical research.  However, to our knowledge these genes have not been implicated in producing variation among wild taxa. We, furthermore, identified a number of novel genes that are likely to play a role in skull development. For example, we identified modifications to growth factor and cytokine signaling that may contribute to the development of jaw shape difference among pupfish. It is furthermore possible that these same genes play an as yet unknown role in hereditary diseases that affect skull shape in humans. Our project thus highlights the potential crosstalk between research in applied fields like biomedical science and in basic science like evolutionary biology.

This project had broader impacts for training, professional development, and education at both the graduate and undergraduate levels. The project trained a graduate student, Ezra Lencer, in conducting and analyzing genomic data, skills both critical to a career in biology and transferable across STEM fields. In addition, this project provided two years of research experience to an undergraduate woman interested in a career in science and public health. Work from this project was integrated into evolution courses at Cornell when appropriate, and has been presented at a number of professional meetings.
